sH4bi60alZU.title: Why are GMOs Bad?
sH4bi60alZU.transcript: Hi! My name is Hank Green and this is SciShow! We made a movie about this before,  but some of the sources we used have proven to be untrustworthy, and we really don't think so  that we were completely told how we are doing with genetic modification  here at SciShow.  Why is GMO bad? It is not - neither in itself, and especially not  for your health. We have eaten it for decades without any harmful effects, which gives  many, for a GMO is just an organism like any other organism,  that make hundreds of thousands of proteins, but which one or two of them are special  selected by us humans.  Genetic modification is necessary for man's continued success here on planet Earth.  Just as the discovery of nitrogen fixation gave us more fertile fields which saved  millions from starvation death, the fruit of genetic modification (quite literally) will help  to meet the great challenges of a world with more people and a climate there  is less and less stable.  Like the nitrogen fix, Germany allowed to build bigger bombs,  genetic modification is a tool that can be used for both good and evil. Therefore, it must be investigated,  controlled and understood. And this understanding starts right here and now with us!  If you live in the United States, you've almost certainly eaten Genetically Modified Organisms,  or GMO: So far, there are only plants, but virtually all kinds of meat on the market  probably got GMO feed.  And it won't be long before the animals themselves are genetically modified. IN 2012  the FDA approved a new type of Atlantic salmon modified to have higher levels of  growth hormone, using genes from Pacific salmon and some kind of eel squash.  They concluded that the modified fish was completely safe and opened the discussion to the public,  but no final decision has yet been made.  GMOs are found everywhere in the United States, quite literally. 95% of sugar beet, 88% of corn,  94% of soybeans grown in the United States have properties - which. eg. insect resistance, or resistance to herbicides-  which they have obtained through genetic modification.  Some crops have been genetically modified just for the benefit of humans. About 500,000 children  becomes blind each year due to vitamin A deficiency. A rice variety has been developed there,  Unlike regular rice, has enough vitamin A to keep children healthy. Or faster,  at least.  The very word "genetically modified" is not true.  Humans have been genetically modified since inventing agriculture.  Every plant species and every animal species has natural variation and the gene pool, and for millennia we have  exploited this variation by practicing artificial selection. We grow and breed organisms  to express their most attractive qualities: runs that make more milk, squash plants that can  survive the drought. Brassica oleracea, better known as wild cabbage, has been bred so intensively  that it is the wild ancestor of half a dozen different garden crops, including broccoli,  cabbage, cauliflower, Brussels sprouts, cabbage rabbit and kale.  Corn initially looked like this. We have made it through years of selective breeding  a giant mutant version that we happily put on the grill without  to think of the centuries of breeding that made it possible to turn a grass seed into a sweet one  and starchy masterpiece.  But when we talk about GMO today, we're really talking about genetically modified  organisms, or transgenic organisms. We're talking about genes from one species there  taken out and then transferred to the genome in another species. This is called transgenesis,  and although not all GMO foods are made this way, transgenic crops are far  the most common kind of genetically modified organism encountered.  There is just that: modified organisms are not new either - we have  peeled at the food in laboratories for almost a hundred years.  In the 1920s, scientists found that they could induce mutations in plants - and thereby  make more genetic variation, and possibly more beneficial traits - by exposing them to  X-rays, gamma rays and various chemicals. In the 1970s, these mutation methods became  quite popular and they were even completely unregulated and ignored by the public.  Thousands of crops formed in this way are on the market today.  It's a pretty rough method - tick the genes, plant the seeds and see  what's happening, and then breed on the cool new properties so we get a new kind of crop.  In 1983, they invented a new technique that took away a gene  an antibiotic-resistant bacterium and spliced ​​it into the DNA of a tobacco plant.  Antibiotic-resistant tobacco obviously has no purpose, but it proved that  one could transmit single genes. A new kind of transgenetics was born.  However, the GMO industry was not able to get a grip until 1994, when the USDA approved  a tomato called Flavr Savr, which was invented by a California biotech company.  The tomato had changed so that it matured slowly and therefore stayed longer.  It was the first genetically modified crop sold to consumers.  However, the Flavr Savr tomato didn't last long - partly because people didn't like the taste,  and partly because Europe in particular was suspicious of its genetics  changes. Flavr Savr, and its barely-so-good taste, sparked a debate there still  going on merrily.  Today, most GMOs cannot be found in the vegetable department, but on the contrary  more than 90% of GMO crops are known as  fodder corn and soybeans, which have been modified to withstand weeds or insects. These crops  used as ingredients in lots of processed food we eat, or used as  feed for animals that we later enjoy eating the meat from.  The best known crop of this kind is the so-called Round-up clear crops -  soybeans, maize, sugar beet, cotton, alfalfa and canola, modified to:  could handle the herbicide RoundUp.  These crops give us some "edible" examples of how transgenic  foods are made, which is why they are made as they are, what they can  and what they cannot.  Let's look at why they were made. The active substance i  the herbicide RoundUp is glyphosate, a chemical that inhibits an enzyme that plants use  to form amino acids. By blocking this enzyme, RoundUp causes the plants to stop producing the substances they need  in order to grow and transform food, and thus it kills them. It works on all plants.  It works so well that they can be difficult to use near plants you do not want to kill,  such as. Crops.  In the 1990s, the company Monsanto, which produces RoundUp, decided to develop crops there  could withstand glyphosate so that farmers could spray the herbicide all over their field,  but only kill the weeds.  There are some microorganisms that make an enzyme that is unaffected by glyphosate.  Monsanto just had to transfer these bacterial genes to crop plants, and so could  farmers use RoundUp to protect their crops without killing them. Small pieces were therefore taken  bacterial DNA encoding the enzyme in question and trying to find out  how to get them into plants.  How to get genes from a bacterium into the cell nucleus of a plant cell. On the Tree of Life  plants and bacteria are not even on the same branch! It turns out that there is one  couple of interesting ways.  The first is a gene cannon.  You heard right: gene guns!  Gene guns do what one would think: literally and slightly chaotic they shoot  DNA into plant cells. They are often used to modify maize and rice species. They use  tiny gold particles covered with hundreds of pieces of DNA from the donor gene  which is called a transgene. The plant cells that will receive the new genes  placed in a vacuum chamber and then released. The DNA-covered gold particles are shot  on the cells using compressed air.  When the gold enters the cell nucleus, it dissolves and the researchers then cross fingers  for the DNA to be taken up by the chromosomes in the cell nucleus, and sometimes  Did it succeed! Once transgenic is inserted into the plant's DNA, it can  themselves are further bred on.  It's not that elegant, but it's much more gentle than just bombarding the seed  with radiation and then hope for the best.  Another newer and more effective method of forming transgenic organisms is provided  to use terrestrial bacteria named Agrobacterium. It is a plant parasite and is nature's own genetic engineer -  it has a little extra piece of DNA called a plasmid that can come  out of the bacterium and implant itself into a plant cell.  In the wild, Agrobacterium uses this little trick to re-encode the plant cells to make them  food for the bacterium. In the laboratory we can use the plasmid some kind of carrier for  smart transgenes, and use it to insert new genetic material into plant cells.  Whether using agrobacterium or gene guns, you now have a new one modified  crop. But it can't just be stuck in the ground -  one has to have the new properties over in the traditional crop plants.  This last step is called back crossing, and involves repeated crossings of the new transgene  plant with crop plants, again and again until you have a new transgenic crop.  Eventually, Monsanto had a patented plant that could withstand spraying  with glyphosate. In the past, plants had to be set at a certain distance  for machines to remove weeds, and it caused land losses and expenses for the farmer,  not to mention high fuel consumption. In addition, Monsanto gets a whole new customer group to buy  It's a long process - the whole molevite can take up to 15 years - but it is  so the way almost all genetic modification takes place in your food,  whether plugging the antibiotic resistance of a bacterium into a tobacco plant or eel worm  growth pattern into a salmon.  Then you have to go through the process of approving the crop or animal,  and it can take many years as well. It is therefore very expensive, but there are  some new technologies that may eventually make it cheaper.  The fact that it is so expensive, yet can pay off, shows where  extremely beneficial GMO crops can be. It also means the companies that make them  keeping them under strict control, and limiting the patents, the cultivation, and even the research as  performed on the crops.  One of the reasons why the fierce attacks on GMOs is not scientific  consequences of their existence, but the economic and cultural consequences of placing  so much power over our food supply in the hands of very few very large companies.  The GMO debate has therefore become a surrogate debate for a much larger debate on economics,  that, frankly, is beyond our reach.  However, there are scientific concerns about GMO food. How to influence  insertion of a single gene, instead of e.g. replace a large piece of the genome, the rest of the genome?  We used to think that it did not affect at all, but it turns out that  the genome is much more complex than that.  Many farmers store non-patented seeds for next year's sowing, but that is not allowed  with patented GMO crops. If your very ordinary seeds became inadvertent  pollinated with a GMO crop, could the seeds you had saved from  last year's harvest, contain genes belonging to some others. And the others,  will sue you. If your livelihood depends on selling certified organic crops or  selling to markets where GMOs are banned can have even greater consequences.  Furthermore, the properties we give to the crops can have ecological consequences:  if we make insect resistance we should make sure that we do not damage insects  which we like, such as bees and butterflies.  After it has been eaten through hundreds of millions of meals by me and probably off  you, and been investigated for decades, there has been zero evidence that  GMO food should be dangerous to human health.  However, it has not stopped loud opponents from supporting miserable studies, and  publish misleading articles.  Here at SciShow, we have even quoted an article claiming that GMOs increase risk  for cancer in rats. The study was done by a guy who didn't quite accidentally publish a book  on the subject the same week as the article was published in a scientific journal,  and was taken for good. But it turned out that data were particularly selected, that there was a lack of effect, that the samples were small  and that the line of rats he was using already had a risk of getting a full 0% cancer, which is why the study  eventually discredited.  As with all new technologies, this can also have unforeseen consequences:  It can be controlled and monopolized and even turned into weapons, so there is plenty of good reason  to keep an eye on the companies that are developing it.  But given the number of hungry people on the planet, we have a commitment  to explore all possibilities to increase the amount of crops, and to limit the amount  of herbicides, insecticides, energy and water consumed in our agriculture. Traditional and advanced  Breeding methods have to be part of this, and so does genetic modification.  Thank you for watching this section of SciShow, and thank you to the people who pushed me  to write a more complete and accurate version of this section. If you want to continue to stay  smarter with us, you can go to youtube.com/scishow and subscribe.

wZ2TF8-PGQ4.description:
Pamela Ronald studies the genes that make plants more resistant to disease and stress. In an eye-opening talk, she describes her decade-long quest to help create a variety of rice that can survive prolonged flooding. She shows how the genetic improvement of seeds saved the Hawaiian papaya crop in the 1950s — and makes the case that it may simply be the most effective way to enhance food security for our planet’s growing population.

TEDTalks is a daily video podcast of the best talks and performances from the TED Conference, where the world's leading thinkers and doers give the talk of their lives in 18 minutes (or less). Look for talks on Technology, Entertainment and Design -- plus science, business, global issues, the arts and much more.
Find closed captions and translated subtitles in many languages at http://www.ted.com/translate

Follow TED news on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/tednews
Like TED on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/TED

Subscribe to our channel: http://www.youtube.com/user/TEDtalksDirector
